Mice heterozygous and homozygous for the targeted mutation are referred to as ? 1 het and ? 1 null, respectively.
A region in the cytoplasmic loop between repeats I and II of the ? 1 subunit, referred to as the AID [ 6], binds tightly with a 30 amino acid region on the ? 1 subunit, referred to as the BID [ 7].

The role of the ? 1 subunit in Ca 2+channel function is of particular interest given the discovery of a second ? subunit, ? 2 or stargazin , which is expressed in neurons and is responsible for the stargazer mutation in mice [ 17].
The relatively long recovery time following the depolarization is due to the low Ca 2+buffering power of the internal recording solution and is in agreement with previous studies [ 27, 30].
The scan direction was perpendicular to the long axis of the myotube in a region selected on the basis of a low resting fluorescence and a high stimulated fluorescence (red/yellow color).

The two traces on top of each image correspond to the time course of the fluo-4 fluorescence averaged across the entire line-scan at -10 mV, which is close to the threshold, and at +90 mV, which produced the maximum Ca 2+transient.
The amount of the ? 1 subunit present in control, ? 1 het and ? 1 null samples as a function of total membrane protein was determined in two independent membrane preparations.
3Bshows the maximum Ca 2+current during the test pulse plotted as a function of the pre-pulse potential.

While this subunit is clearly non-essential for activation of the L-type Ca 2+channel and for triggering skeletal-type EC coupling, ? 1 appears to specifically modulate the Ca 2+channel function of the skeletal DHPR.
Absence of changes in the EC coupling voltage sensor of ? 1nullmyotubes
In summary, the voltage-dependence of Ca 2+transients and the maximum cytosolic Ca 2+concentration during the transient were not significantly affected by partial or total absence of the ? 1 subunit.

Absence of the ? 1 subunit slows inactivation and produces a depolarizing shift in the Ca 2+current inactivation vs. voltage curve, in agreement with results from an independently produced ? 1 knockout mouse [ 20].
Absence of alterations in the voltage dependence of charge movement in the ? 1 null cells should also be reflected in the voltage-dependence of Ca 2+transients.

The results obtained here in skeletal muscle demonstrate that absence of the ? 1 subunit increases Ca 2+current density, decreases the inactivation rate, and shifts the voltage-dependence of inactivation in the depolarizing direction.
In summary, the voltage-dependence of Ca 2+transients and the maximum cytosolic Ca 2+concentration during the transient were not significantly affected by partial or total absence of the ? 1 subunit.
